answer: The annual tech fair where our team built a working robot that could solve a Rubik's cube. We worked for weeks and the applause when it finally worked was unforgettable!
The computer lab on the third floor. It was my sanctuary - always cool, quiet, and filled with the hum of servers. Spent countless hours there learning to code.
I'd organize a coding workshop for students, share industry insights, walk through the old corridors remembering all the moments, and end with cricket on the field with my old team.
Focus on building real projects, not just theoretical knowledge. Learn to work in teams, embrace failure as learning, and never stop being curious. The tech world changes fast - adaptability is key.
The book 'The Pragmatic Programmer' completely changed how I approach software development. It taught me that writing code is about solving human problems, not just technical ones.
Leading the migration of our entire infrastructure to microservices at Tech Mahindra. It took 18 months, but we improved system reliability by 99.9% and reduced costs by 40%.
Playing cricket with my local club every Sunday morning. It keeps me fit, helps me disconnect from work, and the camaraderie reminds me of school days.
'Kal Ho Naa Ho' soundtrack - especially the title track. It always lifts my spirits and reminds me to live in the present moment.
It's a chance to reconnect with the foundations that shaped me. At this stage, giving back and mentoring feels more meaningful than ever. These connections remind me where I came from.
Absolutely! I'd love to mentor students in software engineering, cloud architecture, or career guidance. Also open to collaborating on tech initiatives or speaking at alumni events.
The surprise birthday party my friends threw for me in the cafeteria. They decorated the entire space with handmade posters and brought my favorite chocolate cake. I cried happy tears!
The library reading nook by the big window overlooking the garden. Perfect natural light for studying, and watching seasons change through that window was therapeutic during exam stress.

I'd attend every club meeting to see what students are passionate about now, have lunch with my old teachers to thank them properly, and organize a design thinking workshop to share what I've learned.
Don't be afraid to pivot. Your first job won't define your entire career. Learn to communicate clearly - technical skills matter, but being able to explain ideas to diverse audiences matters more.
Watching 'Everything Everywhere All At Once' made me rethink how we approach product design. It showed me that handling complexity with empathy and humor creates the most meaningful experiences.
Launching a feature that increased accessibility for visually impaired users by 300%. The thank-you emails from users who could finally use our product independently made every late night worth it.
Hiking Bay Area trails on weekends. There's something about being in nature that clears my mind and often leads to my best product ideas. Plus, the photography opportunities are amazing!
'Here Comes the Sun' by The Beatles. It never fails to put me in a positive mindset, especially during tough product launches or challenging stakeholder meetings.
In my 30s, I'm finally understanding the value of long-term relationships. These are people who knew me before LinkedIn profiles and job titles - that authenticity is rare and precious.
Definitely! I'd love to mentor students interested in product management, UX design, or transitioning into tech. Also happy to collaborate on alumni networking events or career workshops.
The drama production of Macbeth where I designed all the stage sets and costumes. Seeing my creative vision come to life on stage with 500 people watching was pure magic.
The art studio with its huge windows and paint-splattered floors. That space represented freedom - a place where making mistakes was encouraged and creativity had no boundaries.
I'd teach a design workshop showing students how art meets technology, visit the art studio to see what young artists are creating now, and sketch portraits of teachers who inspired me.

Develop a strong portfolio early - it speaks louder than grades. Learn to take criticism constructively. Most importantly, understand that design is about solving problems for real people, not just making pretty things.
Visiting the Tate Modern's 'Turbine Hall' exhibition changed everything. I realized that design isn't confined to screens or paper - it's about creating experiences that move people emotionally.
Winning the 'Accessible Design Award' at BBC for redesigning our news platform to serve users with various disabilities. Making information accessible to everyone is design's highest calling.
Practicing traditional calligraphy every evening. The meditative quality of ink flowing on paper helps me disconnect from digital work and reconnects me with the fundamental principles of design.
'Clair de Lune' by Debussy when I need to focus, and 'Mr. Blue Sky' by ELO when I need energy. Music shapes my creative mood like nothing else.

At 41, I'm realizing that career success means little without meaningful connections. This group represents shared history and values - it grounds me when the modern world feels too fast and transactional.
Absolutely! I'd love to mentor aspiring designers, critique portfolios, or lead workshops on inclusive design. Also interested in collaborating on projects that give back to our school community.

The science fair where our group's solar panel project won first place. We stayed up all night before the presentation fixing bugs. That feeling of teamwork under pressure taught me everything about DevOps!
The rooftop terrace where we'd go between classes. The view of the city skyline reminded me there was a whole world out there waiting. Plus, best spot for deep conversations with friends.

I'd shadow different teachers to see how education has evolved, organize a 'Women in STEM' panel discussion, practice yoga on the sports field at sunrise, and properly thank the teachers who believed in me.

Build a strong foundation in fundamentals - they don't change as fast as frameworks. Find allies and mentors. Don't wait for permission to lead. And please, prioritize work-life balance from day one - burnout is real.
Reading 'Educated' by Tara Westover reminded me how privileged my access to education was. It made me committed to volunteering and making tech education accessible to underrepresented communities.

Reducing deployment time from 6 hours to 15 minutes through CI/CD automation at Shopify. It sounds technical, but it meant developers could ship features faster and spend more time with their families.
Teaching coding to girls aged 10-14 in underserved communities every Saturday. Watching them go from 'I can't do this' to building their first apps is the highlight of my week.
'Titanium' by David Guetta feat. Sia. The lyrics about being bulletproof and resilient perfectly capture how I approach challenges in the male-dominated tech industry.
In my late 30s, I'm focused on legacy and impact. Reconnecting with this group reminds me of my roots and inspires me to mentor the next generation. We're stronger together than apart.

100% yes! I'm passionate about mentoring women in tech, DevOps engineering students, or anyone transitioning into cloud computing. Also open to speaking at events or collaborating on diversity initiatives.
The leadership camp in Year 11 where we spent a week doing team-building exercises in the mountains. Learned more about myself and leadership in that week than in any classroom before or since.
The quiet corner of the main building near the principal's office. Sounds odd, but there was this bench with a view of the entire campus. Perfect place for reflection and strategic thinking.

I'd meet with current students to understand their career aspirations, have coffee with old teachers who shaped my thinking, sail a boat on the nearby harbor if possible, and attend a school assembly to feel that energy again.

Develop critical thinking and communication skills - AI can't replace those. Build a diverse network early. Don't chase titles; chase learning and impact. And remember: every expert was once a beginner.
Attending a conference on 'Regenerative Business Models' completely shifted my perspective from profit-first to planet-first thinking. True innovation must consider environmental and social impact.
Leading a digital transformation project that saved a struggling retail chain while preserving 2,000 jobs. Consulting isn't just about efficiency - it's about people's livelihoods and communities.
Sailing Sydney Harbour every weekend. The combination of strategy, weather reading, teamwork, and connection to nature provides the perfect counterbalance to consulting's mental intensity.
'Three Little Birds' by Bob Marley. 'Every little thing gonna be alright' is my mantra before big client presentations or when projects get tough. Never fails to center me.

At 43, life is less about climbing ladders and more about meaningful relationships. This alumni group represents authenticity and shared values in a world that often feels superficial. It's about returning to roots.

Absolutely! I'd love to mentor students interested in consulting, digital transformation, or sustainable business practices. Also keen to collaborate on alumni events, guest lectures, or social impact projects.
